newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Feb 7.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Feb 7.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

Average weekly earnings figures released yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveal that wages increased by 1.2 per cent in the three months to November 1996, pushing the over-the-year growth rate to 3.9 per cent. The latest figures have dealt a blow to the prospect of a further cut in interest rates for this year. Page 1.

An independent review of Government film funding, released yesterday, has recommended new measures to stimulate private investment in the film industry and the outsourcing of Film Australia's film and television productions. The review, chaired by David Gonski, also argues that the Federal Government should continue to fund the A$1.2 billion sector directly. Page 2.

Following the High Court's Wik decision, the National Party is pushing to lock its Liberal Coalition partners into proposing legislation to extinguish native title on pastoral leases. However an Aboriginal delegation has warned the Federal Government that extinguishing native title would create permanent divisions, hostilities and scars within the community. Page3.

European Union Commissioner for Agriculture, Dr Franz Fischler, has attacked Australia's strict quarantine laws, claiming they are being used as a subtle means of restricting trade. Although acknowledging the need for the quarantine restrictions, Fischle said they should not be used as a non-tariff barrier to imports. Page 4.
THE AUSTRALIAN

The chance of a change in official interest rates before the outcome of the Industrial Relations Ruling on the ACTU's 'living wage' diminished yesterday when official figures revealed wages growth was between 3.8 per cent in August and 3.9 per cent in November. The Federal Government used the latest figures to attack the trade union movement claim of a 'living wage'. Page 1.

Trade tensions between the European Union and Australia heightened yesterday when the EU's agriculture commissioner, Dr Franz Fischler accused Australia of using 'subtle' trade barriers. The top farm official claimed Australia was one of the 'so-called' fee trading countries who used quarantine barriers to exclude European producers from markets. Page 1.

In a rare insight into the pressures of life on the bench, according to one of Australia's most senior judges, Justice Kirby of the High Court, the modern judiciary is composed of overstressed, overworked, depressed and even potential suicide cases. Kirby blamed crushing workloads, media scrutiny and scarce resources as the reasons for the problems. Page 1.

Prime Minister John Howard told a delegation of Aboriginal leaders that he was prepared to take a direct role in a national round-table conference to help resolve uncertainty over native title following the Wik decision. The Prime Minister also refused to rule out any amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act as part of a Federal Government response to the Wik ruling. Page 3.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Aboriginal groups have warned the Federal Government that they will choose their own representatives for Wik negotiations, following fears that the Prime Minister and his native title team were trying to lock out outspoken black leaders which include Pete Yu, Noel Pearson and Mick Dodson. Page 1.

NSW Police are investigating whether some Sydney taxi operators are trying to save money by making the vehicles safety airbag inoperative. The revelations have surfaced following a coronal inquest into a female driver who was killed in a taxi which had its airbag disconnected. Police believe some drivers may disconnected airbags fearing they will inflate in minor collisions and add to repair bills. Page 1.

As the Senator Bob Woods affair deepens, the Prime Minister John Howard admitted he was first told of a police investigation into the Senator for alleged misappropriation of a travel allowance last September. However the Prime Minister denied he had breached his own code of ministerial conduct by suggesting earlier this week he had only known of the investigations for no more than 10 days ago. Page 1.

The NSW Attorney-General Jeff Shaw lashed out at proposed Federal cuts to legal aid yesterday, claiming the effects of the A$120 million cut to the national legal aid budget could result in the prospect of 'criminals walking free'. The NSW Government has roposed to break away from the national legal aid system and fund only those cases brought under NSW laws. Page 3.
THE AGE

The Federal Government is under pressure to find a new home for Australia's nuclear waste following revelations that a storage centre for spent fuel rods will be full by the end of this year. The Lucas Heights reactor in Sydney may have to be shut once th limit is reached. Page A1.

The managing director of cinema chain Village, Graham Burke, has rejected any link between a A$100,000 donation to the Victorian Liberal Party and the desire of Village to see a US cinema group's plans of a "megaplex" scuttled. Page A1.

The Environment Protection Authority has taken the rare step of warning swimmers to stay out of Port Phillip Bay on Victoria's eastern coastline. The warnings came as hundreds of swimmers were stung by jellyfish which have flourished in the soaring tempertures. Page A1.

Victoria's first law ombudsman last month received over 200 inquires - mostly complaints -from people unhappy with their dealings with the legal profession. Independent legal watchdog, Marg O'Donnell said the high inquiry rate showed there was need for th ombudsman and education about the legal system. Page A2.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
